Nate Agrin home writings resume portfolio

Education

Master of Information Management Systems, May 2008

University of California at Berkeley; Berkeley, California.
Focus: User centered design, information visualization and social uses of information.

Bachelor of the Arts in Molecular Biology, May 2002

Clark University; Worcester, Massachusetts.
Graduated with Highest Honors, Phi Beta Kappa National Honor Society Member.

Work Experience

User Interface Engineer, July 2008 – Present

Splunk Inc. San Francisco, California.

  • Worked as part of a small team rewriting and rearchitecting the user interface powering Splunk’s log file search engine.
  • Communicated with other in-house development groups to facilitate rapid development during a period of swift growth.
Lead Web Architect, September 2007 – July 2008

iNaturalist.org Berkeley, California.

  • Worked as part of a group of three developing a community driven web application allowing naturalists to record what species they’ve observed in the wild.
  • Developed dynamic user interfaces and information visualizations, integrating numerous web-based services including Google Maps, Flickr photos, and Google Charts.
  • Work accepted as part of a talk at the 2010 Where 2.0 conference.
User Interface Engineer, July 2007 – December 2007

Bolt | Peters, Ethnio.com
San Francisco, California.

  • Revitalized the online user recruiting service Ethnio by designing new user interfaces and remodeling workflows based on past users º feedback.
  • Worked as part of a team of three rewriting existing code using a test-driven development process.
Lead Developer, October 2005 – May 2007

Center for History and New Media, Omeka.org
George Mason University; Fairfax, Virginia.

  • Lead a team of three in building the open-source web archive application, Omeka.
  • Successfully deployed large online archives using Omeka, and integrated applicable web-services such as Google Maps to create insight into each digital archives’ collection.
Cell Biology Researcher, October 2002 – October 2004

University of Massachusetts at Worcester
Worcester, Massachusett.

  • Discovered and sequenced novel proteins in the research organism Chlamydomonas. Results published in the Journal of Cell Biology, presented at the 2003 Cell Biology Conference.
  • Recommended the creation of and built an online repository to store the results of each experiment using open-source technologies. Cross referenced other biology based web-services, expanding the insight into each novel protein discovered and while also providing access for outside researchers.
